thread.title: Veterans to stage 'Julius Caesar' through Feast of Crispian program
thread.title_full: Veterans to stage 'Julius Caesar' through Feast of Crispian program

title: Veterans to stage 'Julius Caesar' through Feast of Crispian program
text:
Veterans to stage 'Julius Caesar' through Feast of Crispian program By Jim Higgins of the Journal Sentinel Oct. 26, 2015 10:11 a.m. (0) Comments 
Veterans who are using Shakespeare's conflicts to work through their own challenges with trauma, addiction and emotional health will perform "Julius Caesar" beginning Thursday at Next Act Theatre. 
The non-profit Feast of Crispian program began in 2013. Local theater professionals, including Nancy Smith-Watson, Bill Watson and Jim Tasse, rehearse scenes with veterans of all ages and branches. In a recent article, Smith-Watson told Associated Press reporter Carrie Antlfinger that the acting process helps veterans access blocked emotions by using Shakespeare's words, and builds their confidence. 
While Feast of Crispian has presented scenes publicly before, this is the group's first full production of a Shakespeare play. In announcing the production of Julius Caesar, Smith-Watson noted that Shakespeare's historical drama "explore(s) differences in beliefs about how best to fight a battle, how to maintain relationships while being a soldier and how to maintain a sense of self." 
Performances take place at 7 p.m. Oct. 30 and 31, 2 p.m. Nov. 1 at Next Act Theatre, 255 S. Water St. 
Tickets are free; donations are accepted. Reservations are required. Call (414) 278-0765. Â© 2015 , Journal Sentinel Inc. All rights reserved. About Jim Higgins
